   Assessment and Plan
 PANCREATITIS, ACUTE
 MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION, ACUTE (AMI, STEMI, NSTEMI)
   # Pancreatitis/Cholangitis: Pt noted to have cholangitis and
   pancreatitis on ERCP examination, two stones were extracted from the
   ampulla and common hepatic duct, a sphincterotomy was performed. Pt
   received approx 4.5L  NS IVF hydration for his pancreatitis. LFTs and
   Lipase this AM show a downward trend.
   - Will continue Zosyn for enteric coverage and Vancomycin for Gram
   positive coverage
   - Will continue IVF 150cc/hr LR maintenance
   - Will trial on clears and ADAT
   - Morphine 2-4mg  q4hr IV PRN pain
   - Pt still hypovolemic, Pancreatitis fluid needs similar to burn pt
   needs, will continue 500cc LR bolus x 2. Pt
s PO intake should also
   increase with clear diet in place.
   .
   #. Hypotension: After induction yesterday pt was noted to be
   hypotensive to the SBP 70s, on arrival to the floor pt was on pressor
   support however after transfer to his bed his MAPs were noted to be >65
   without pressor support. Since this event pt
s SBP have ranged from mid
   80s to 110s and appear to be fluid responsive. Current hypotension most
   likely hypovolemic given the fluid loss involved with pancreatitis.
   Will continue to IVF bolus with LR for a goal MAP >65.
   - IVF fluid for MAPs >65
   .
   # [**Last Name (un) **] on CKD: Pt has histroy of CKD with a baseline Creatinine of
   1.7-1.9. Pt's Creatinine currently elevated at 2.4 increased from 2.2.,
   most likely pre-renal versus ATN given his pancreatitis. In spite of
   the increase in pressure pt
s UOP has still remained borderline which
   may indicate a marker of pre-renal failure.
   - Will renally dose all medications
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Trend Creatinine
   - Obtain urine lytes
   - Will currently hold on AEI and [**Last Name (un) **] therapy
   .
   # DM II: Per [**Name (NI) **] pt usually takes Glyburide 5mg once a day, will
   transition pt to insulin sliding scale particularly given his NPO
   status and likely increased insulin needs given his infectious state.
   - Check CBGs qACHS
   - Will continue ISS as pt is only on clears diet, will switch to Lantus
   coverage when pt tolerates solid PO.
   - Will transition back to Glyburide prior to discharge
   - Will currently hold ACEI and [**Last Name (un) **] therapy given pt's current [**Last Name (un) **].
   .
   # systolic CHF: Pt on prior echo noted to have a reduced EF of 40% with
   a fixed Apical defect. Pt on afterload therapy with Lisinopril and
   Valsartan per [**Last Name (un) 2040**].
   - Will currently hold ACEI and [**Last Name (un) **] as pt has [**Last Name (un) **]
   - Will use caution with IVF hydration given depressed systolic function
   .
   #  Sinus Tachycardia: Pt has been sinus tachycardic overnight, sinus
   tachycardia most likely a component of his still present hypovolemia
   and pain.
   # Access: 2 PIV
   .
   # PPx: Pantoprazole, Heparin SC TID
   .
   # Code:  FULL CODE
   .
   # Comm: (Son) [**Name (NI) 5449**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5450**]

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a well-nourished elderly Caucasian male who is currently intubated in the ICU. The patient underwent an ERCP procedure yesterday, which revealed two irregular stones in the common bile duct (one impacted in the ampulla) and common hepatic duct. Mild dilation of the biliary tree and drainage of infected black bile were also observed.

The patient's vital signs are as follows: Tcurrent: 36.7°C (98.1°F), HR: 119 bpm (with a normal range of 73-119 bpm), BP: 109/67 mmHg (with a normal range of 82-136/40-88 mmHg), RR: 26 breaths per minute (with a normal range of 11-32 breaths per minute), and SpO2: 98%.

The patient has a history of acute pancreatitis, acute myocardial infarction (AMI), and chronic kidney disease (CKD). The patient's blood glucose level is within normal range.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a well-nourished elderly Caucasian male who was admitted with acute pancreatitis and cholangitis. He underwent an ERCP procedure which showed two irregular stones in the common bile duct and common hepatic duct, with mild dilation of the biliary tree and drainage of infected black bile. The patient received approximately 4.5L of normal saline IVF hydration for his pancreatitis, and his lipase levels are showing a downward trend.

The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a baseline creatinine of 1.7-1.9. His current creatinine level is elevated at 2.4, which may indicate pre-renal failure or acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Given the large amount of fluids received since the ERCP, the patient's renal output has not shown vast improvement. Therefore, it is important to obtain urine electrolytes to assess for ATN and trend creatinine levels.

The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus type II and is currently NPO (nothing by mouth). Insulin sliding scale will be started due to his NPO status and likely increased insulin needs given his infectious state. Glyburide will be transitioned back prior to discharge.

Additionally, the patient has systolic heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction of 40%. Afterload therapy with Lisinopril and Valsartan will be continued, but caution should be exercised with IV

Summary:
The patient is an elderly Caucasian male with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II, and systolic heart failure (HFrEF). He presented to the hospital with symptoms consistent with acute cholangitis and acute pancreatitis. The patient underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) which revealed two irregular stones in the common bile duct and common hepatic duct. A sphincterotomy was performed, and the stones were extracted.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia, mild hypotension, and an increased respiratory rate. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 100%. The patient's blood glucose level is elevated, and his liver enzymes and lipase are significantly increased. His serum creatinine level is slightly elevated as well.

The patient has multiple medical complications including acute myocardial infarction (AMI), acute pancreatitis, cholangitis, and possible pre-renal acute kidney injury (AKI) due to dehydration. He also has a history of CKD with a baseline creatinine of 1.7-1.9.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and pancreatitis following an ERCP procedure. The patient has acute renal failure (ARF), oliguria/anuria, and elevated creatinine levels. He also has acute myocardial infarction with elevated cardiac markers. The patient is currently hypotensive and requires pressor support. He is experiencing abdominal pain, tenderness in the right lower quadrant, and diminished peripheral pulses. His respiratory status is stable, but he is tachycardic and has low oxygen saturation. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease with a baseline creatinine of 1.7-1.9. He is currently on insulin for diabetes management and has a reduced ejection fraction of 40% with a fixed apical defect. The patient's blood glucose levels are being monitored closely, and he is on various medications for his conditions, including anticoagulation therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's worsening renal function, as indicated by the increasing creatinine levels, suggests the possibility of AKI. This could be due to a combination of factors such as dehydration, use of nephrotoxic medications, or underlying chronic kidney disease.

Summary:
The patient is a 55-year-old male with a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD), diabetes mellitus type II, systolic heart failure, and a recent episode of pancreatitis. He presented to the emergency department with cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. Since then, he has been in the ICU for ongoing management.

24-hour events:
- Advanced to clear liquids
- FENa was 0.5% and urinalysis showed 3 WBC, few bacteria, but negative leukocyte esterase and nitrites
- Given 500 cc and 250 cc LR bolus today
- HR slowly trended up, appeared to be sinus tachycardia
- Foley catheter was removed due to persistent discomfort
- Labs showed worsening acute renal failure (ARF) with creatinine increasing from 2.4 to 3.6 and potassium increasing to 5.5. Started on metoprolol for tachycardia and kayexalate for hyperkalemia
- UOP continues to decrease throughout the day, possibly indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal consult today. Fluid boluses did not help
- Previously on pressors only during ERCP, now extubated and doing well
- Unable to provide history due to language barrier
- No known drug allergies
- Last dose of antibiotics: Vancomycin on 12/19/22 at 07:26

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of deafness who has undergone an ERCP procedure. He initially presented with sepsis and two stones were removed. The patient successfully underwent extubation and weaning off pressors. However, he has developed early renal failure with suggestions of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) as the primary insult. There has been some improvement in the abdominal exam, but the patient continues to have persistent renal failure.

The patient's medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cholangitis: The patient is already on antibiotics (Vanco/Zosyn), and the plan is to continue advancing his diet per GI. Monitoring for any signs of worsening infection or sepsis is crucial.

2. Acute Renal Failure (likely ATN): The patient's urine output is severely impaired, indicating oliguria/anuria. Maintaining euvolemia, following urine output, consulting with a renal specialist, and administering renal dose medications are necessary to manage this condition.

3. Sepsis: Despite the ongoing antibiotic course, the patient's WBC count remains elevated. Continuous monitoring of the exam for recurrence of sepsis is essential, and the patient should be encouraged to mobilize early.

Other potential medical complications mentioned in the note include pancreatitis, myocardial infarction (AMI), and DVT. However, there is no specific information provided about these conditions at this time.

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and now presents with acute renal failure, respiratory failure, pancreatitis, myocardial infarction, oliguria/anuria, and hypotension. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with baseline creatinine levels of 1.7-1.9. His current creatinine level is 5.9, indicating worsening renal function. The patient also has metabolic acidosis, likely lactic acidosis, and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with a femoral dialysis line. 

Medical Complications:
1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has ARF with an elevated creatinine level from 1.7-1.9 to 5.9. This could be due to multiple factors such as sepsis, hypotension, or nephrotoxins. The patient is on CVVH and renal dosing of medications.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has respiratory failure, likely secondary to prolonged hyperventilation with metabolic acidosis. He is intubated and receiving sedation with fentanyl and versed.
3. Pancreatitis/Cholangitis: The patient

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for acute kidney injury (ARF) after undergoing an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for cholangitis.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical issues:

1. Pancreatitis/Cholangitis: The patient had cholangitis and pancreatitis during the ERCP examination. Two stones were extracted from the ampulla and common hepatic duct, and a sphincterotomy was performed. The patient received approximately 4.5 liters of normal saline intravenous fluid hydration for his pancreatitis. Liver function tests (LFTs) show a downward trend.

2. Hypotension: The patient has experienced recurrent hypotension, initially noted to be in the 70s systolic blood pressure (SBP), and later improved to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 without the need for pressor support. Possible etiologies include cardiac ischemia with continuing elevated cardiac enzymes (CK and Troponin-T), pulmonary embolism (PE), cardiac tamponade (although the electrocardiogram (EKG) has remained unchanged), or sepsis. Bilateral large bore lines have been ordered, cycling central venous pressure (CVP), transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), and continuous renal monitoring for possible pressors overnight. Fluid boluses are to be given as needed.

3. Acute Kidney Injury (CKD): The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a baseline creatinine level of 1.7-1.9. His current creatinine level is elevated to 4.3, suggesting acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Renal dosing of medications, avoidance of nephrotoxins, trend creatinine, obtain urine electrolytes, and hold angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) and [Last Name (un)] therapy have been advised.

4. Diabetes Mellitus Type II (DM II): The patient is on insulin for glycemic control, and his usual oral hypoglycemic agent (Glyburide) has been temporarily discontinued. Regular blood glucose monitoring is recommended, and the patient will transition back to Glyburide prior to discharge.

5. Systolic Congestive Heart Failure (systolic CHF): The patient has a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) of 40% with a fixed apical defect. Medications such as Lisinopril and Valsartan have been prescribed. The patient's angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) and [Last Name (un)] therapy have been temporarily held. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male admitted for cholangitis and acute renal failure. He underwent an ERCP procedure but developed complications including hypotension and anuria. The patient's condition has been stable, with mild elevations in transaminases but no worsening trends. However, there is a significant increase in creatinine to 6.0, indicating worsening renal function. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be preload-dependent, and he has shown improvement with volume support. The possibility of a pulmonary embolism (PE) should also be considered, as it can cause acute changes and hypotension. Further investigation is needed to confirm this diagnosis.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's anuria and elevated creatinine levels indicate acute renal failure. Continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) may be necessary to manage the volume, acidemia, and electrolyte imbalances. Acid-base status will need to be closely monitored and corrected accordingly.
3. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangitis is being managed with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. Antibiotic therapy should continue, and the underlying cause of the cholangitis should be addressed.

Other Considerations:
- Pancreatitis: The patient's elevated amylase and lipase levels suggest acute pancreatitis. Monitoring and supportive care are essential.
- Myocardial Infarction: The

Summary:
The patient's medical history is significant for congenital deafness, hypertension (HTN), diabetes mellitus (DM), coronary artery disease (CAD), osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. The patient was admitted after an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for cholangitis and now presents with acute renal failure (ARF), respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and possible myocardial infarction (MI).

The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with baseline creatinine levels of 1.7-1.9. Currently, the patient's creatinine level is 4.0 after starting continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) yesterday. The bicarbonate level also improved to 19 this morning from low 14 prior to starting CVVH. The patient's urine output has been low, with only 128 mL of urine output since admission.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, and they are currently intubated. They have worsening metabolic acidosis despite being hyperventilated for over 24 hours. The arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.41, PaCO2 of 31, HCO3 of 19, and a base excess of -3. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100% on a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). The patient now presents with acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure (ARF), oliguria/anuria, acute pancreatitis, and suspected myocardial infarction.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to hyperventilation for more than 24 hours with metabolic acidosis. He is intubated and receiving sedation with fentanyl and versed. An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows a pH of 7.41, PaCO2 of 31 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 218.

The patient has ARF with a baseline creatinine of 1.7-1.9 and current creatinine of 5.9. There is also evidence of metabolic acidosis, possibly lactic acidosis. Renal dosing of medications is being done, and efforts are being made to avoid nephrotoxins. Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) has been initiated.

The patient also has evidence of acute pancreatitis and cholangitis, as stones were extracted from the ampulla and common hepatic duct during the ERCP procedure. His

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for acute cholangitis and underwent an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Since then, he has developed respiratory failure, acute renal failure, pancreatitis, and suspected myocardial infarction. The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease with baseline creatinine levels between 1.7-1.9, and his current creatinine level is 4.0 after starting continuous venovenous hemodialysis (CVVH) yesterday. His bicarbonate level also improved from 14 to 19 this morning. The patient's urine output has been low, with only 23 mL in the last 24 hours. He is currently on pressure support and receiving sedation with fentanyl and midazolam. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Weaning to pressure support may be attempted today.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, likely secondary to sepsis and/or hypotension. His serum creatinine has risen to 4.0, indicating significant kidney dysfunction. CVVH has been initiated, and efforts are being made to optimize fluid and electrolyte balance.

The patient was admitted after undergoing an endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for cholangitis and is currently experiencing acute renal failure (ARF), respiratory failure, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction.

The patient has a baseline creatinine level of 1.7-1.9 and his creatinine peaked at 6.0 prior to starting continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH). The etiology of ARF is still uncertain, as muddy brown casts were not present on the urine exam yesterday. The patient is currently on renal dosing medications including vancomycin every 24 hours while on CVVH. The goal is to maintain an even I-O today and keep the patient stable, avoiding diuresis if possible. If the patient is sedated, it is important to have a family member or interpreter present to explain the situation, particularly regarding CVVH.

The patient also has respiratory failure and is intubated. There is a plan to wean sedation and attempt extubation today if possible. A chest X-ray will be performed to check for evidence of pulmonary edema. Inhalers will be started today, and the ABG will be re

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of biliary obstruction, now post-endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), and worsening renal failure in the setting of resolving sepsis.
- The patient has intubation due to severe volume overload and acidosis.
- CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) has been started and has improved the patient's blood chemistry, including metabolic acidosis.
- The patient also has acute respiratory failure, not ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome), and is being weaned off sedation with a low respiratory rate.
- The main concern for extubation is volume overload in the setting of CVP (central venous pressure) elevation and 2 liters positive across the day.
- The patient remains oliguric/anuric, indicating reduced urine output.
- Pancreatitis is much improved.
- Hypotension is being managed by maintaining an adequate CVP, preserved cardiac function, and decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
- There are no signs of sepsis, so heparin will be continued, along with repeat lactate, cultures, cortisol, TSH, and fungal cultures if necessary.
- The patient is currently on vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn).
- ICU care includes nutrition via nasogastric tube, regular insulin sliding scale for glycemic control,

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. Post-procedure, he developed respiratory failure and acute renal failure. He also has pancreatitis, myocardial infarction, hypotension, leukocytosis, and possible ileus. The patient's current medical complications include respiratory failure, acute renal failure, oliguria/anuria, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure, likely due to hyperventilation and worsening metabolic acidosis. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which could be attributed to various factors such as sepsis, nephrotoxic medications, or underlying chronic kidney disease. He is undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) to manage fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Oliguria/Anuria: The patient is producing very little urine, indicating oliguria or anuria. This may be a result of acute renal failure or other underlying conditions.
4. Pancreatitis: The patient has acute pancreatitis, which could be related to his recent ERCP procedure. He is at risk for complications such as pancreatic

The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a baseline creatinine level of 1.7-1.9. His creatinine peaked at 6.0 prior to starting continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH). The patient has a bicarbonate level that is stable but still shows a metabolic gap and non-gap acidosis.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to prolonged hyperventilation for more than 24 hours, leading to worsening metabolic acidosis. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and hypertension. He was admitted with cholangitis and post-intervention complications, including acute renal failure, hypotension, and respiratory failure. The patient is currently in the ICU and is being managed for several medical complications.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been diagnosed with respiratory failure. The plan is to perform a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) for 30 minutes, check an arterial blood gas (ABG) at 30 minutes, and attempt extubation if the SBT is favorable. If the SBT is unfavorable, the patient will return to continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) with negative fluid balance.

2. Sepsis: The patient has persistent and intermittent hypotension in the setting of volume removal. This is being treated for the original insult. Additionally, there are concerns raised for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection due to an elevated white blood cell count. A C. diff culture will be done, and empiric treatment with Flagyl will be provided.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure. CVVH will continue, and a negative fluid balance will be maintained today. An HD catheter is already in place.

4. Oliguria/Anuria: The patient is experiencing decreased urine output.

5. Acute Pancre

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. Post-procedure, he developed respiratory failure, acute renal failure, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction. Potential Medical Complications:

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. The patient is currently experiencing multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, acute renal failure, oliguria/anuria, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode. His vital signs include a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 105/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient has a white blood cell count of 25.8 K/uL and elevated creatinine levels. He has been receiving various medications including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and renal dosing medications. The patient's medical team is considering hemodialysis and further imaging studies such as a CT scan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. The patient was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. Since then, the patient has developed several medical complications.

The patient has respiratory failure, acute renal failure, oliguria/anuria, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction. The patient's respiratory failure is likely not associated with ARDS. The acute renal failure may be due to the underlying CKD, as the patient's baseline creatinine levels were 1.7-1.9 and peaked at 6.0 prior to starting CVVH. The presence of non-gap acidosis with bicarbonate levels stable suggests a metabolic cause for the renal failure.

The patient also has evidence of pancreatitis and cholangitis, as indicated by the ERCP examination showing stones in the ampulla and common hepatic duct. The patient is currently experiencing ileus, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

The patient's hypotension after the ERCP procedure could be due to various causes such as cardiac ischemia, pulmonary embolism, tamponade, sepsis, or other factors. The patient is currently on pressor support, and further investigations are needed to determine the underlying cause.

   83 yo male with initial presentation with biliary obstruction and
   patient had failed extubation yesterday with what was likely related to

   at re-intubation.  He now is faced with substantial rise in WBC count
   despite start for C. Diff Rx yesterday.  This may be in part
   attributable to SIRS insult from re-intubation yesterday.  This raises

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of biliary obstruction who presented with respiratory failure, hypotension, and renal failure. The patient underwent invasive ventilation and had recurrent hypotension requiring re-intubation due to substantial central airways wheezing. The patient also has ileus noted on CT scan and is unable to create a negative fluid balance. The patient's condition is complicated by transient esophageal intubation and likely aspiration of bilious contents. 

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has respiratory failure, which is not consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The plan is to continue with pressure support ventilation (PSV) and ensure adequate volume removal before attempting extubation again. Chest X-ray is reassuring, and steroids will be continued for upper airway patency.

2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, and fluid removal should be held. Urine output is minimal, and continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) should be continued.

3. Oliguria/Anuria: The patient is experiencing minimal urine output.

4. Acute Pancreatitis: Although the patient's pancreatic enzymes have normalized, fluid management for pancreatitis will be continued.

5. Myocardial Infarction: The patient's cardiac enzymes have improved in the setting of acute respiratory failure from yesterday.

6. Sepsis/Hypotension: There is concern for toxic megacolon,

Chief Complaint: 83 yo M w/ h/o congenital deafness, HTN, DM, CAD,
   osteoarthritis and L subclavian steal syndrome admitted s/p ERCP for
   cholangitis now with ARF s/p  resp failure.

   steroids.  Reintubation complicated by intubation into esophagus with
   aspiration as lg amts bile suctioned from lungs after placement of ETT
   in trachea.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. Post-procedure, he developed respiratory failure and was intubated. He also has acute renal failure and pancreatitis. The patient has been experiencing hypotension, leukocytosis, ileus, and possible abdominal abscess. He is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics, antidiabetics, and cardiac support. The patient's medical team is monitoring his condition closely and is considering further interventions such as CVVH, HD, and imaging studies.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Complications: Given the patient's respiratory failure and prolonged intubation, there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), atelectasis, and lung infection.
2. Renal Complications: The patient has acute renal failure, and there is a possibility of further deterioration in kidney function. This could lead to the need for ongoing renal support or dialysis.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, which may progress to necrosis or develop complications like pseudocysts or abscesses.
4. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and ileus raise concerns about the possibility of an abdominal abscess or infection. This would require appropriate imaging and antibiotic management

The patient has been intubated multiple times due to respiratory fatigue and has undergone an ERCP procedure. He is currently on prolonged mechanical ventilation with pressure support and is being treated for various conditions including pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, and sepsis. The patient's renal function is compromised, and he requires continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) with fluid restriction. His blood glucose levels are being monitored closely due to diabetes mellitus. The patient also has a history of systolic heart failure and is on afterload therapy with Lisinopril and Valsartan. His current code status is full code.

1. Prolonged mechanical ventilation: The patient has been intubated multiple times and is currently on prolonged mechanical ventilation with pressure support. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory muscle weakness.

3. Ileus: The patient has ileus, but no obstruction on the CT scan.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure and will continue with CVVH. There is hope for the return of renal function.
5. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis associated with significant elevation in WBC count, and there is concern for Clostridium difficile (C. Diff). Alternative sources have not been seen, and the patient has persistent moderate acute pancreatitis. The treatment plan includes continuing with C. Diff treatment, Vanco/Zosyn antibiotics, Flagyl for C

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's chief complaint is cholangitis, sepsis, and hypoxia. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and has undergone several medical interventions.

1. The patient has a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome.
2. The patient presented with respiratory failure, presumed due to volume overload in the setting of acute kidney injury and anuria. Previous attempts at extubation were unsuccessful due to wheezing and presumed continued fluid overload. However, the patient's lungs are currently clear to auscultation bilaterally, and continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) was able to remove fluid yesterday. Therefore, the presumed etiology of extubation failure has reversed, and the patient had a spontaneous breathing trial this morning with stable ventilation and oxygenation. The plan is to extubate the patient.
3. The patient has acute kidney injury (ARF) secondary to chronic kidney disease (CKD), with a baseline creatinine of 1.7-1.9. The patient's creatinine peaked at 6.0 prior to starting CVVH. The etiology of ARF with the absence of muddy brown casts originally on microscopic urine exam is still uncertain. Renal dosing of medications, including vancomycin Q24 while on CVVH, is being implemented.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. The patient is currently experiencing multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, acute renal failure, ileus, pancreatitis, and myocardial infarction. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 35.9°C, heart rate of 116 bpm, blood pressure of 136/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on nasal cannula.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure presumed due to volume overload in the setting of acute kidney injury and anuria. There have been previous attempts at extubation that were unsuccessful. Currently, the patient's lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) was able to remove fluid yesterday. Therefore, the presumed etiology of extubation failure has reversed, and the patient had a spontaneous breathing trial this morning with stable ventilation and oxygenation. Extubation is planned.

2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with a baseline creatinine level of 1.7

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted for cholangitis and underwent an ERCP procedure. The patient is now experiencing multiple medical complications, including acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, oliguria/anuria, acute pancreatitis, and possible myocardial infarction.

Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient initially had respiratory failure due to volume overload, metabolic acidosis, and fatigue. After failed extubation, he was reintubated but successfully extubated on [**12-28**]. His lungs are now clear bilaterally, and he is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

2. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) with baseline creatinine levels of 1.7-1.9. His creatinine peaked at 6.0 before starting CVVH. The etiology of ARF is uncertain, with no muddy brown casts observed on microscopic urine examination. Renal replacement therapy, including CVVH and hemodialysis (HD), has been initiated.

3. Oliguria/Anuria: The patient has reduced urine output, which may be related to his renal failure.

4. Acute Pancreatitis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has several medical complications. These include:

1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is suspected to have a PE, which is a blockage in one or more arteries in the lungs. This can be life-threatening and requires immediate treatment.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient initially experienced respiratory failure due to volume overload and metabolic acidosis. Although the patient's current oxygen saturation (SpO2) is good, there may still be ongoing respiratory issues.

3. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient has acute renal failure, as indicated by the elevated creatinine levels. This is a serious condition where the kidneys suddenly stop working properly.

4. Oliguria/anuria: The patient is experiencing decreased urine output, which is a sign of kidney dysfunction.

5. Pancreatitis: The patient has acute pancreatitis, which is inflammation of the pancreas. This condition can lead to complications such as infection or organ failure.

6. Myocardial infarction (MI): The patient had an acute myocardial infarction, also known as a heart attack. This is indicated by elevated cardiac markers (CK/CKMB/Troponin-T) and symptoms like chest pain.

7. Cholangitis: The patient had cholangitis, which is an infection of the bile ducts. This condition often requires intervention through procedures like ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography).

8. C. diff colitis: The patient is suspected to have Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, which is a bacterial infection of the colon. This can cause severe diarrhea and abdominal pain.

9. Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive at times, indicating low blood pressure. This can be due to various causes, including sepsis, heart problems, or fluid loss.

10. Cardiac ischemia: The patient has had ongoing cardiac ischemia, which means there is reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. This can lead to further complications if not treated promptly.

11. Ileus: The patient has ileus, which is a condition where digestion and bowel movement are temporarily slowed or stopped. This can occur after abdominal surgery or as a result of certain medications.

12. History of congestive heart failure (CHF): The patient has a history of systolic CHF and is on afterload therapy with Lisinopril and Valsartan. The patient also has moderate left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) and a slightly reduced ejection fraction (LVEF 45-50%).

13. Diabetes mellitus type II (DM II): The patient has DM II and is usually on Glyburide 5mg once a day. The patient is currently on insulin for glycemic control.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congenital deafness, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary artery disease, osteoarthritis, and left subclavian steal syndrome. He was admitted after an ERCP procedure for cholangitis and is currently experiencing multiple medical complications.

24-hour events include the removal of an additional 2 liters of fluid, plan to discontinue vancomycin and zosyn antibiotics in the morning, initiation of a clear diet, and ordering physical therapy and occupational therapy. The patient will undergo a tunnelled hemodialysis line placement in the interventional radiology department tomorrow. An epoetin order has been placed for renal recommendations, and a PICC line has been requested. Enemas and suppositories have been given, and total parenteral nutrition (TPN) will continue.

The patient is in sinus rhythm.
